titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Johannes Eldert papers 1977.651
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-19 15:35:15 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection includes two documents dated 1812-1817: an inventory of items in the home of Thomas W. Hunt in the town of New Lots and an inventory of goods in Margaret Eldert's estate.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The papers were formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder with no particular arrangement.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Margaret Eldert died in Brooklyn in 1817.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The town of New Lots later became part of the East New York neighborhood of Brooklyn.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Johannes Eldert papers, 1977.651, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes an inventory of items in the home of Thomas W. Hunt in the town of New Lots, taken by Johannes Eldert in exchange for $75 rent that Hunt owed; and an inventory of goods in Margaret Eldert's estate.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
